title: Witch Hats - Cellulite Soul [2008/MP3/V0/Log]
description:
Tracklisting

   1. Before I Weigh
   2. I Cant Stay At Home
   3. Climing Up Yr Cable
   4. Western&#039;
   5. HellHole
   6. Potaoto Feet
   7. Summer Of Pain
   8. Ma Lord
   9. Neil Diamond Entry
  10. Door Films

MESS+NOISE article

Witch Hats are four brats who play disagreeably loud songs and misspell half the tracks on their debut album. I love them, sort of. Last year when they played the much-delayed Cellulite Soul in its entirety at one of those alleyway venues Melbourne is known for, a sizable chunk of the audience walked out covering their ears. At the time I thought there must have had been a mistake, but no ÃƒÂ¢?? the record is just as loud. The band plunder the bottom-end of Australian underground music history ÃƒÂ¢?? bassist Ash Buscombe boasts an impressive collection of original Scientists singles ÃƒÂ¢?? and play pop songs that sound as if they&#039;d spent twenty years in a trashcan before stumbling to life. One of the more merciful things about hearing Witch Hats on record is being able to turn them down occasionally.

Cellulite Soul&#039;s first track &#039;Before I Weigh&#039; kicks off with a warbled scream and a guitar so distorted it would make The Jesus And Mary Chain proud. Kris Buscombe&#039;s voice is almost inaudible ÃƒÂ¢?? the album doesn&#039;t come with a lyric sheet, by the way ÃƒÂ¢?? before all four of them join in to sing a catchy but incomprehensible chorus twice in a row. That&#039;s more or less the formula for Cellulite Soul ÃƒÂ¢?? two parts dumpster and one part melody. Half-way through there&#039;s a particularly good song called &#039;HellHole&#039;, which is probably the loudest of the bunch and one of the rare moments you can understand the lyrics. Each verse is a play on the first one: "Dude, stop sitting in the apple tree/ The damn thing&#039;s shaking violently." The apple tree eventually falls on top of the protagonist and drags everyone into the "hellhole" of the chorus. There&#039;s something so childish and sinister about that track, placed right at the very heart of Cellulite Soul, that speaks volumes. Witch Hats play a kind of music close to my heart ÃƒÂ¢?? the abyss as pop song. This is a brilliant album.

by Andrew Ramadge
